titleInfo.title: Emerson Nathaniel Bell oral history interview

mods.abstract: Bell discusses how his upbringing in South Baton Rouge encouraged him to explore the arts, which came naturally to him. He recalls the influence of his arts education by family members, friends, and other artists in the community. He describes his early works and traces the influence of various artists who instilled in him the values of simplicity, sincerity and hard work. He recalls influences and opportunities in New Orleans, Chicago, New York, Detroit, Canada and Japan. He expounds on the spiritual influences on his work and how he still draws inspiration from his early life experiences. Finally, he discusses teaching young artists and urging them to resist material interests and build their confidence.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.1594. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Barbara Faulkner.

Emerson Bell, known for his sculpture, printmaking and painting, was born in Baton Rouge, La. Bell attended McKinley High School, the Central Area Vocational School, and he studied at the John Payne National College and Charles Wilson Fine Arts Academy. He also studied under Alvin Batiste at Southern University. He served in the army from 1953 to 1955, and was stationed in Japan and South Korea. Bell received grants from the Ford Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts and was the first artist-in-residence in the Baton Rouge Public School System, where he taught art for many years. Bell passed away in 2006 at age 74.
